page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY - HEDINGHAM
page.content: There is a mention of Castle Hedingham in the original Domesday Book. This was a busy and prosperous place in the middle ages and into the 17th c. when it was a market town, but it is now a quiet village with many buildings (Listed) from the past in a very good state of preservation. Hedingham Castle was built by Aubrey de Vere about 1140, but the Keep is all that now remains. The de Veres became the Earls of Oxford and remained in the village until 1625. They built St. Nicholas Parish Church, and the Nunnery, now a private farm, which was founded for Black-veiled nuns in 1190. Woollen cloth was produced until the early 19th c. Hedingham pottery was produced here in the 19th c. by Edward Bingham.
